articles.headline: Vulnerable Democrats See Fates Tied to Clinton
articles.snippet: Some House Democrats are concerned over the possibility that Hillary Rodham Clinton will be their party nominee.
articles.abstract: Some House Democrats are concerned over the possibility that Hillary Rodham Clinton will be their party nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANHATTAN, Kan. — Nancy Boyda, a Democrat who ran for Congress in this district last year, owed her upset victory partly to the popularity of the Democratic woman at the top of the ticket: Kathleen Sebelius, who won the governor’s seat. Now, with a tough re-election race at hand in 2008, Ms. Boyda faces the prospect that her electoral fate could be tied to another woman: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

articles.headline: A Lurid Aftermath to a Hedge Fund Manager’s Life
articles.snippet: The unfolding drama over Seth Tobias’s estate is providing a racy account of fast money and faster living in the volatile world of hedge funds.
articles.abstract: The unfolding drama over Seth Tobias’s estate is providing a racy account of fast money and faster living in the volatile world of hedge funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — A life of private jets and black-tie balls ended with Seth Tobias, a wealthy investment manager and a familiar presence on CNBC, floating face down in the swimming pool of his mansion here.

articles.headline: Life Was Lost in Maelstrom of Suspicion
articles.snippet: A suicide threatens to plunge the Air Force into a quagmire as it struggles to emerge from a huge scandal.
articles.abstract: A suicide threatens to plunge the Air Force into a quagmire as it struggles to emerge from a huge scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — Friends of Charles D. Riechers, whose Air Force career took him from the back of a B-52 cockpit to the front of the service’s $30 billion procurement office, said something was telling in the fact that his suicide note to his boss was typed. They described it as an effort to set the record straight by a meticulous man who felt deeply misunderstood.
articles.byline: By Ginger Thompson and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: In Alaska’s Far North, Two Cultures Collide
articles.snippet: The traditions of the Inupiat, natives of Alaska’s arid north coast, are coming into conflict with the quest for oil.
articles.abstract: The traditions of the Inupiat, natives of Alaska’s arid north coast, are coming into conflict with the quest for oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARROW, Alaska — Each summer and fall, the Inupiat, natives of Alaska’s arid north coast, take their sealskin boats and gun-fired harpoons and go whale hunting. Kills are celebrated throughout villages as whaling captains share their catch with relatives and neighbors. Muktuk, or raw whale skin and blubber, is a prized delicacy.

articles.headline: U.S. Finds Iran Halted Its Nuclear Arms Effort in 2003
articles.snippet: A new assessment by American intelligence agencies, which concludes that Iran’s weapons program is on hold, contradicts a report two years ago that Tehran was working inexorably toward building a bomb.
articles.abstract: A new assessment by American intelligence agencies, which concludes that Iran’s weapons program is on hold, contradicts a report two years ago that Tehran was working inexorably toward building a bomb.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — A new assessment by American intelligence agencies released Monday concludes that Iran halted its nuclear weapons program in 2003 and that the program remains frozen, contradicting a judgment two years ago that Tehran was working relentlessly toward building a nuclear bomb.

articles.headline: Serving Life for Providing Car to Killers
articles.snippet: An American legal doctrine makes accomplices as liable as the killer for murders committed during felonies.
articles.abstract: An American legal doctrine makes accomplices as liable as the killer for murders committed during felonies.
articles.lead_paragraph: CRAWFORDVILLE, Fla. — Early in the morning of March 10, 2003, after a raucous party that lasted into the small hours, a groggy and hungover 20-year-old named Ryan Holle lent his Chevrolet Metro to a friend. That decision, prosecutors later said, was tantamount to murder.

articles.headline: Calculating Energy Bill’s Real Figures
articles.snippet: Auto policy experts were still struggling on Monday to determine exactly what the effects would be under the energy compromise reached by Congressional leaders last week.
articles.abstract: Auto policy experts were still struggling on Monday to determine exactly what the effects would be under the energy compromise reached by Congressional leaders last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — Gas mileage would go up under the compromise reached by Congressional leaders last week, but not as high as the trumpeted numbers. And despite the tougher 35 m.p.g. standard, a growing population of drivers would push up total fuel use, as well as greenhouse gas emissions — but not as rapidly as would occur without the legislation.

articles.headline: Paulson Sees Limited Aid in Rate Plan
articles.snippet: The Bush administration’s effort to help borrowers in danger of defaulting on their subprime mortgages could help only a small number of those who took out such loans.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration’s effort to help borrowers in danger of defaulting on their subprime mortgages could help only a small number of those who took out such loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — The Bush administration’s effort to help borrowers in danger of defaulting on their subprime mortgages could help only a small number of those who took out such loans, industry analysts said Monday.

articles.headline: Venezuela Vote Sets Roadblocks on Chávez Path
articles.snippet: The surprising defeat of a referendum to accelerate President Hugo Chávez’s socialist-inspired revolution has given new energy to his long-suffering opposition.
articles.abstract: The surprising defeat of a referendum to accelerate President Hugo Chávez’s socialist-inspired revolution has given new energy to his long-suffering opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 3 — The surprising defeat of a referendum over the weekend to accelerate President Hugo Chávez’s socialist-inspired revolution has given new energy to his long-suffering opposition.
